newsitem.title: USA: Oxis International completes Phase I trial.
newsitem.headline: Oxis International completes Phase I trial.

text.p: Oxis International Inc said Tuesday it has successfully completed a Phase I trial of BXT-51072, a drug to treat diseases associated with damage from free radicals and reactive oxygen species.
The trial tested the compound in a series of mimics of the natural antioxidant enzyme, glutathione peroxidase.
The company said in a statement its plans to move forward with a Phase II trial of BXT-51072 in inflammatory bowel disease in 1997, pending regulatory review.
The placebo-controlled, Phase I trials were conducted in the United Kingdom and evaluated the safety of single and multiple doses of BXT-51072 in healthy volunteers.
"We are pleased with the results of the trials," said Chief Operating Officer Timothy Rodell, M.D.
"The drug was well absorbed by the oral route and no significant safety issues were seen," he added.

BXT-51072 was designed to protect cells from the damage caused by free radicals and reactive oxygen species, which are toxic molecules produced as a result of normal metabolism and present in increased levels in certain inflammatory conditions.
The company said it believes the drug will be useful in treating several diseases.

OXIS is also developing a second series of lipid soluble antioxidant compounds for potential use in treating specific dermal and ophthalmic diseases, and pursuing a discovery phase program in the cancer area.
